TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi sealed X509ContentType extends System.Enum

Docs.summary: Specifies the format of an X.509 certificate.

remarks.format: ## Remarks Content types F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509ContentType.Cert?qualifyHint=False&autoUpgrade=True, F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509ContentType.Pkcs12?qualifyHint=False&autoUpgrade=True, and F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509ContentType.SerializedCert?qualifyHint=False&autoUpgrade=True can be exported as byte arrays. Therefore, all three formats are serialized certificates. F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509ContentType.SerializedCert?qualifyHint=False&autoUpgrade=True differs from an exported F:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509ContentType.Cert?qualifyHint=False&autoUpgrade=True file in that it is created by using the [CertSerializeCertificateStoreElement function](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=183293), which serializes both the encoded certificate and its encoded properties. If you export the same T:System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509Certificate?qualifyHint=False&autoUpgrade=True object in both formats and view the resulting byte arrays, you will see that the two are different.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509ContentType Authenticode = int32(6)
.field public static literal valuetype System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509ContentType Cert = int32(1)
.field public static literal valuetype System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509ContentType Pfx = int32(3)

Docs.summary: A PFX-formatted certificate. The `Pfx` value is identical to the `Pkcs12` value.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509ContentType Pkcs12 = int32(3)

Docs.summary: A PKCS #12–formatted certificate. The `Pkcs12` value is identical to the `Pfx` value.
